words.def: In a tournament, the scheme for the progression of players and boards from table to table, arranged so that a pair does not play the same boards twice, or meet the same opponents twice etc. The most common movements for pairs tournaments are Howell and Mitchell.
words.name: Movement

words.def: A 4–3 trump fit, or a contract with such a trump fit. Named after The Bridge World editor Alphonse "Sonny" Moyse Jr, who wrote and published a variety of articles that promoted the virtues of such fits or contracts, some bidding styles designed to locate them, and some techniques for playing them well.
words.name: Moysian fit

words.def: Acronym of "Middle, Up, Down", a lead convention which describes the sequence in which cards from a holding of three low ones (all less in rank than the 10) are played.
words.name: MUD

words.def: An ambiguous opening bid of 2♦ that promises one of several different types of hand.
words.name: Multi

words.def: A call which indicates either: (1) a willingness to play the contract named, (2) a suit bid suggesting length or strength in that suit, (3) a notrump bid that suggests a balanced hand, (4) a double that suggests the ability to defeat the opponent's contract, (5) a redouble to suggest that the contract can be made in the face of a double by opponents, or (6) a pass that suggests weakness, satisfaction with the last bid made or no desire to make a further call. Contrast Artificial.
words.name: Natural

words.def: Nederlandse Bridge Bond (Dutch Bridge League).
words.name: NBB

words.def: A conventional call used by responder in a competitive auction to denote possession of at least one unbid suit.
words.name: Negative double

words.def: Responder's suit bid following an opening bid and an overcall. Nonforcing by prior agreement.
words.name: Negative free bid

words.def: An inference based on something that did not happen. For example, if a defender does not overruff, declarer might conclude that he could not overruff. Or if declarer does not ruff a loser in dummy, a defender might conclude that declarer does not have a loser in that suit.
words.name: Negative inference

words.def: A bid that shows insufficient values for a stronger response. For example, a 2♦ response to a forcing 2♣ opening bid is often negative, as is a 1♦ response to a Precision 1♣.
words.name: Negative response

words.def: In a competitive auction, the double of a voluntarily bid slam to show no defensive tricks, and therefore to suggest a sacrifice.
words.name: Negative slam double

words.def: In duplicate pairs tournaments, a method of fairly adjusting match point scores when not all boards have been played the same number of times. It gives equal weight to each board by calculating the expected number of match points that would have been earned if the board had been played the full number of times.
words.name: Neuberg formula

words.def: By agreement, after 1m - 1M; 1NT, a bid of two of the unbid minor as artificial and forcing, often requesting three card support for responder's bid major or four cards in the unbid major. Sometimes called PLOB.
words.name: New minor forcing

words.def: A suit that has not yet been bid.
words.name: New suit

words.def: New minor forcing.
words.name: NMF

words.def: An alternative to "pass". Used in the United Kingdom, where "pass" might be mis-heard as "hearts." Regarded as improper in the US.
words.name: No bid

words.def: A suit which has not yet been bid by either opponent.
words.name: Nonadverse suit, or non-adverse suit

words.def: A bid which partner may pass. See also Forcing bid, Invitation, Sign-off.
words.name: Nonforcing bid, or non-forcing bid

words.def: Not vulnerable.
words.name: Nonvulnerable, or non-vulnerable

words.def: In rubber bridge, the state of the score in which neither pair has made a game. In duplicate bridge, the vulnerability condition under which neither pair is designated as vulnerable for the board in play. Also, "neither side vulnerable."
words.name: None vulnerable

words.def: One of the partnerships designated on duplicate boards.
words.name: North–South

words.def: The state of vulnerability in which both bonuses and penalties are smaller. Therefore, less is at stake for a non-vulnerable pair investigating game or slam, or that is contesting the part score, than for a vulnerable pair. Also, "non-vulnerable."
words.name: Not vulnerable

words.def: A contract, or a bid that names a contract without a trump suit. Notrump is the highest-ranking strain. WikiProject Contract bridge deprecates the two-word "no trump", however "no trump" is the usual spelling in the United Kingdom and in those European countries which have adopted this English term.
words.name: Notrump, or no trump (NT)

words.def: Balanced distribution. WikiProject Contract bridge deprecates the two-word "No Trump".
words.name: Notrump distribution, no trump distribution, or NT distribution

words.def: Non-playing captain.
words.name: NPC, or npc

words.def: An interference bid whose principal aim is not to preempt or to compete for the contract, but nevertheless to upset the smooth flow of the opponents' bidding sequence.
words.name: Nuisance bid

words.def: A very large penalty: "He went for a number." Often, "telephone number", alluding to the size of that number if regarded as a quantity. (Dating back to the 1930s when UK telephone numbers were only four figures, plus an exchange name!)[citation needed] See also
words.name: Number, as "go for a number"

words.def: 1) Of a finesse: A duck, made in the hope that a high card will fall. For example, declarer holds ♥K432 opposite dummy's ♥Q765. The ♥2 is led to the ♥Q, which wins. Declarer now leads dummy's ♥5 and RHO follows with the ♥J. Declarer ducks, hoping that LHO must now play the ♥A. The play is obligatory because given the first heart trick, no other play can yield three tricks.2) Of a falsecard: A falsecard that, like an obligatory finesse, cannot lose and might gain. An example is the play of the card that one is known to hold (for example, the play of a queen after it has been successfully finessed).
words.name: Obligatory

words.def: Specifying a level. To make 4♥ is to make four-odd.
words.name: Odd

words.def: A defensive carding scheme under which the play of an odd-numbered card is encouraging and that of an even-numbered card is discouraging. The rank of the card may be used to show suit preference.
words.name: Odd–even discards

words.def: The number of tricks above six (the book) that are taken by declarer.
words.name: Odd tricks

words.def: 1) (Slang) Down, or set. "We're off two" means "We have made two fewer tricks than our contract."2) (Slang) offside.
words.name: Off

words.def: Having a distribution that does not quite conform to that suggested by a bid, such as an opening bid of 1NT with 2=2=6=3 shape, or a weak-two bid with a seven card suit.
words.name: Off shape, offshape, or off-shape

words.def: Said of some number of tricks that can be lost or won without gaining or losing the lead. "There were eleven tricks off the top in spades", to mean that declarer could take eleven tricks without interruption; or, "We're down off the top", to mean that the defenders can take at least four immediate tricks against 4♥.
words.name: Off the top

words.def: Unfavorably located, from the point of view of the player taking a finesse. If East holds the ♣K and North the ♣AQ, from South's point of view the ♣K is offside. Contrast Onside.
words.name: Offside

words.def: A world bridge championship held every four years under the auspices of the World Bridge Federation.
words.name: Olympiad

words.def: 1) Makeable. A contract that can be made is said to be on.2) Onside.3) (Suffix) In rubber bridge, preceded by a number that indicates progress toward game. If one has 40 points Below the line, one has 40-on.
words.name: On

words.def: A bidding system that uses a bid of 1♣ as artificial and forcing, but not necessarily strong.
words.name: One club system

words.def: To an opening one-bid, any one-level response in a suit; that is, one of a higher suit in response to opening one of a lower suit. Contrast Two over one.
words.name: One over one, or one-over-one (1/1)

words.def: A bid that requests partner to ensure that the bidding continue for at least one more round. If partner's RHO bids, partner may pass, but is otherwise expected to bid.
words.name: One round force

words.def: A hand with only one long suit, normally refers to a hand with a six card or longer suit.
words.name: One-suiter

words.def: Favorably located, from the point of view of the player taking a finesse. If West holds the ♣K and North the ♣AQ, then from South's point of view the ♣K is onside. Contrast Offside.
words.name: Onside

words.def:
1) In the auction: To start the bidding by making the first call other than Pass.2) Of a room used at a team event: allowing spectators. Normally at least one of two rooms is closed to spectators.3) Of an event: not restricting entries in some way that is implicit. So participation in an open event is unrestricted in at least one respect:

a) not by invitation only (invitational event)
b) not by qualification in a preceding event or qualifier
c) not by representation of geographic zones, nations, cities, clubs, etc; nor by requirement that pair or team members share geographic residence, club membership, etc (national event, etc)
d) not by age, sex, or playing record (seniors, Masters, etc).

Open is generally ambiguous but it does have the last sense (d) in the names of WBF world championship events, where the relevant Categories are Youth (with subcategories), Seniors, Women, and Open. For the WBF, transnational means open in sense (c).
words.name: Open

words.def: The player who makes the opening bid.
words.name: Opener

words.def: Opener's second bid.
words.name: Opener's rebid

words.def: The first bid in the auction.
words.name: Opening bid

words.def: The first card led by defenders. The dummy is not faced until after the opening lead, which makes the choice of opening lead more difficult than other leads. The opening lead can determine the outcome of the deal.
words.name: Opening lead

words.def: The declarer's LHO, who always makes the opening lead.
words.name: Opening leader

words.def: A member of the other partnership or team.
words.name: Opponent

words.def: In unopposed bidding, the contract that cannot be improved upon by further bidding, nor could have been improved upon by taking a different line in earlier bidding. The contract is regarded as optimum because it offers the maximum score while minimizing the risk of failure.
words.name: Optimum contract

words.def: (Informal) A hand on which "our" side can take more tricks than their side.
words.name: Our hand

words.def: See Advance cue bid.
words.name: Out-of-the-blue cue bid

words.def: See In back of.
words.name: Over

words.def: 1) (Noun) A bid that overstates a hand's strength.2) (Verb) To bid voluntarily to a contract that the partnership cannot make.3) (Verb) To bid too high, irrespective of the result.4) (Noun) In British texts, may refer to an overcall.
words.name: Overbid

words.def: (Slang) Having overbid.
words.name: Overboard

words.def: The first bid made by one of opener's opponents unless they intervene first by a double.
words.name: Overcall

words.def: The player making an overcall; may also be referred to as the intervenor. Contrast Advancer.
words.name: Overcaller

words.def: To ruff with a higher trump following a prior ruff on the same trick.
words.name: Overruff

words.def: To play a card higher than the winning card played by partner, unnecessary to win the trick but necessary to gain the lead.
words.name: Overtake

words.def: A trick taken by declarer beyond the number of tricks required by the contract.
words.name: Overtrick

words.def: Deck of cards.
words.name: Pack

words.def: Two players playing bridge together as partners. Partnership.
words.name: Pair

words.def: A form of duplicate bridge in which each pair competes separately, as distinct from team and individual events. Pairs events are normally scored by matchpoints.
words.name: Pairs

words.def: (Slang) Someone who plays bridge worse than others in their usual level of play
words.name: Palooka

words.def: A defence to a Strong Club whereby two-level bids show the suit bid or the other 3 suits.
words.name: Panama

words.def: On a given deal, the score that results from best bidding and best play by both sides. See optimum contract and par contract.
words.name: Par, or par score

words.def: A competition that uses composed deals, designed to test each pair's bidding and its card play. After the bidding, pairs are instructed to play (or defend) a specified contract. Results are compared not with other tables but with the predetermined par result.
words.name: Par contest

words.def: That contract which results from optimal bidding by both sides, and which neither side could improve by further bidding.
words.name: Par contract

words.def: (Slang) Partner.
words.name: Pard

words.def: 1) A trick score less than 100, obtained by making a contract.2) The contract that results in that trick score.3) In rubber bridge, a total of fewer than 100 points below the line.
words.name: Part score, or part-score

words.def: A part score.
words.name: Partial

words.def: An endplay in which declarer is unable to remove all possible safe defensive exit cards, and must hope that the remaining cards are so distributed that the defense cannot get off lead safely.
words.name: Partial elimination

words.def: The other member of the partnership.
words.name: Partner

words.def: 1) See pair.2) Two partners who play together for an extended period.3) The complete set of agreements entered into by a pair.
words.name: Partnership

words.def: Sequences in which the opponents do not compete.
words.name: Partnership bidding

words.def: A service, provided by some tournaments, that locates a partner for a player who does not yet have one.
words.name: Partnership desk

words.def: An agreement between partners, reached prior to the beginning of play, concerning the meaning of a call or of carding.
words.name: Partnership understanding, or partnership agreement

words.def: 1) A call indicating that the player does not wish to change the contract named by the preceding bid, double or redouble. To pass transfers the right to make the next call to passer's LHO, unless it is the third consecutive pass, which ends the bidding (but see Passed out).2) To play, from third hand, a lower card than the one led to the trick. If declarer leads the ♥J, LHO plays a small heart, and declarer plays the ♥2 from dummy's ♥AQ2, declarer has passed the ♥J.
words.name: Pass

words.def: To make a forcing pass and on the next round remove partner's double by bidding.
words.name: Pass and pull

words.def: A player who passed instead of opening the bidding. The inference is that a passed hand does not hold the values required to open the bidding (unless playing a strong pass bidding system).
words.name: Passed hand

words.def: 1) A deal is passed out if the auction begins with four consecutive passes. There is no contract, no play of the hand, and (at rubber bridge) no score. The players proceed to the next deal.
words.name: Passed out

words.def: An approach to defending a hand that emphasizes waiting for tricks that declarer must eventually lose, getting off lead safely, and avoiding plays that will set up tricks for declarer. Often indicated when neither declarer nor dummy has a running side suit or when the declaring side may have over-reached in the bidding. Contrast Active.
words.name: Passive defense

words.def: A bid made in response to partner's ambiguous call. For example, South opens with 1♠ and West bids 2♠, by prior agreement showing hearts and a minor. North passes and East bids 3♣, expecting West to pass if he holds clubs and to correct to diamonds otherwise.
words.name: Pass-or-correct

words.def: 1) To make the third of three consecutive passes following a bid, double or redouble.2) To make the fourth of four consecutive passes. Thus, a bid cannot have been made and the table progresses to the next deal.3) (Adjective) The seat where a pass would end the auction.
words.name: Pass out

words.def: See distribution.
words.name: Pattern

words.def: High card points plus number of spades held. See Hand evaluation.
words.name: Pearson points

words.def: 1) A score awarded to the defense when declarer's contract goes down. The size of the penalty depends on the number of tricks that declarer was set, the vulnerability, and whether the contract was doubled, or redoubled. See Score.2) A remedy assigned by a director to redress damage done by an infraction. The penalty for a minor, procedural infraction might be some number of tricks, matchpoints or IMPs, or disallowing a particular bid or play. A more serious violation of the game's Proprieties may be imposed by barring the offender from an event, a portion of an event, or from organized bridge.
words.name: Penalty

words.def: A card, incorrectly exposed by the defense, whose subsequent proper play is governed by certain rules. See major penalty card and minor penalty card.
words.name: Penalty card

words.def: See double
words.name: Penalty double

words.def: The pass of an informatory double, to convert it to a penalty double.
words.name: Penalty pass

words.def: A play that is chosen because the mathematics of suit distribution suggests that it is more likely to succeed than an alternative line. Usually said of play in a single suit rather than the hand as a whole.
words.name: Percentage play

words.def: A record of the board number, opposing pair number, contract, declarer, tricks taken, and raw score kept by each player for the boards played by the partnership in a single session. The personal score often appears on the back of the convention card.
words.name: Personal score

words.def: (Slang; chiefly British) See Echo. The term is said to derive from Blue Peter, a nautical signal.
words.name: Peter

words.def: In a pairs movement, if there is an odd number of pairs, then in each round one pair will have to sit out. The missing pair that they would have played is known as the phantom pair.
words.name: Phantom pair

words.def: A sacrifice bid against a contract that the opponents would not have made. Also, False sacrifice.
words.name: Phantom sacrifice

words.def: A type of 1 Club opening bid which shows opening values but does not guarantee clubs, denies a five card major (and often 5 diamonds as well) and may have as little as one club (on a 4441 shape hand). Usually played as forcing for one round. A variant of a short club.
words.name: Phoney club

words.def: (Slang) A hand that is so easy it plays itself. "Pianola" is a trademarked brand of player piano (a piano that plays automatically).
words.name: Pianola

words.def: 1) (Verb) To run a suit without losing a trick in it.2) (Adjective) Said of a partner who completes a pair, or of a pair that completes a team, just prior to the start of an event.
words.name: Pick up

words.def: A type of score slip on which the result of a deal is recorded for the purpose of comparative scoring. Used in certain event formats, it is picked up after each round by the director or his caddy. Also referred to as a pick-up card.[6] Contrast Traveller.
words.name: Pick-up slip

words.def: The lead of a high card from one hand to capture a singleton of lower rank in an opponent's hand.
words.name: Pin

words.def: 1) A spot card.2) A suit symbol (♠, ♥, ♦, ♣) on a card.
words.name: Pip

words.def: To discard.
words.name: Pitch

words.def: 1) (Adjective) Of the suit that both defenders must guard in a double squeeze.2) (Verb) In party bridge, to change partners while remaining at the same table.3a) (Verb) In duplicate bridge, to play one round in a given direction, and the next round in the opposite direction at the same table3b) (Noun) In duplicate bridge, a pivot table is a table where each pair will perform a pivot. This can only happen in a Howell movement, or another similar movement, where players move between East-West and North-South during the course of the game.
words.name: Pivot

words.def: A French, whist-like card game whose scoring foreshadowed that used in contract bridge.
words.name: Plafond

words.def: A suit that is not trump; a side suit.
words.name: Plain suit

words.def: 1) (Noun) The stage of a deal when players attempt to take tricks. The declarer tries to take at least as many tricks as the contract calls for, and the defenders try to prevent that outcome.2) (Verb) To contribute a card to a trick, either by displaying its face (as in duplicate bridge) or by placing it face up on the table (as in rubber bridge).
words.name: Play

words.def: To assume that the opponents have a particular distribution or holding, and to plan and conduct the play on that basis.
words.name: Play for

words.def: 1) (Of a contract) A rational, if not necessarily optimal, choice of strain and level.2) (Of an agreement) Leading to an acceptable result, if not in the best fashion.
words.name: Playable

words.def: Cards, such as long cards, that will take tricks (usually, for declarer), and that therefore contribute to a hand's strength.
words.name: Playing tricks

words.def: Acronym or initialism for Petty Little Odious Bid, another name for New Minor Forcing. The name is derived from a diatribe by The Bridge World editor Alphonse "Sonny" Moyse Jr in the magazine's Master Solver's Club feature, which called the convention an "odious, meaningless, petty little bid".
words.name: PLOB

words.def: One of four slots in a duplicate board that hold the cards between plays.
words.name: Pocket

words.def: A proxi-acronym for Pass=0, Double=1. Method for countering interference over Blackwood. Pronounced "podey".
words.name: PODI

words.def: 1) A scoring unit: e.g., a trick taken by declarer in a minor suit contract scores 20 points.2) A metric used in hand evaluation, to quantify its strength in high cards and distribution.3) A metric, such as masterpoints, used in rating players.
words.name: Point

words.def: Another name for board-a-match.
words.name: Point-a-board

words.def: A method of hand evaluation which assigns a numeric value to a hand's high cards and distributional features, used as a guideline in bidding.
words.name: Point count

words.def: Spades or diamonds. The term refers to the shape at the tops of the suit symbols. Contrast Rounded suit.
words.name: Pointed suit

words.def: A bridge club in London which published the first version of the Laws of contract bridge. The club remains part of the ongoing process of revising the laws, along with the ACBL and the EBL, because of the vesting of the copyright.
words.name: Portland Club

words.def: (Noun) Seat at the table: North, South, East, West; or first, second, third, fourth.
words.name: Position

words.def: A squeeze that can succeed against only a specific opponent, because at least one threat must lie over its guard. Compare with Automatic squeeze.
words.name: Positional squeeze

words.def: A bid that announces the possession of at least minimum values. Often said of a response to a forcing opening bid. Contrast Negative response.
words.name: Positive response

words.def: (Slang) A discussion of a hand, and the nature of the result, after the play has concluded.
words.name: Post mortem

words.def: An unusually strong hand.
words.name: Powerhouse

words.def: An alert which must be made at the beginning of the round before play begins on the first board. Different national governing organizations may establish different requirements for prealerts. Examples of methods for which the ACBL requires a prealert include the following:
words.name: Prealert

words.def: A bidding system that combines the features of Kaplan–Sheinwold with a strong, artificial 1♣ opening bid.
words.name: Precision, or Precision Club

words.def: 1) A bid (or raise) predicated on length of a suit rather than overall strength, primary function of which is to interfere with the opponents' bidding by taking away bidding space they need to exchange information.2) (Noun) A bid that has a preemptive effect, regardless of its intent.
words.name: Preempt, preemptive bid, or preemptive raise

words.def: A call that returns the bidding to partner's first-bid suit; for example, in 1♥ - 1♠; 2♦ - 2♥, 2♥ is a preference. A simple, non-jump preference shows neither strength nor support for the suit; it is simply a return to partner's presumably longer suit.
words.name: Preference

words.def: A bid which differs from usual partnership practice that is chosen to avoid a later bidding problem. For example, playing five-card majors and holding a minimal strength opening hand, a strong four-card spade suit may be opened in preference to a weak five-card heart suit. See also prepared opening bid.
words.name: Prepared bid

words.def: See short club.
words.name: Prepared club

words.def: A carding agreement under which a count signal shows the number of cards currently held. In a count-giving situation, a defender might first play the ♥3 from ♥753, and the ♥7 as his second play. Also, "current count."
words.name: Present count

words.def: A guideline to the play of the hand, concerning the probability of the location of key cards in the unseen hands. In particular it states that if a defender plays one of two adjacent missing cards (e.g. ♦QJ) then that defender is less likely also to hold the other missing card.
words.name: Principle of restricted choice

words.def: The movement of players and deals between rounds in an event.
words.name: Progression

words.def: A squeeze in three suits that, when it matures, results in a new squeezed position in two suits.
words.name: Progressive squeeze

words.def: 1) In the play, to cause a card to become a winner.2) In the bidding, to assign a higher value to a card, or to the hand as a whole, as a result of earlier calls made by partner or by the opponents.
words.name: Promote

words.def: A section of the Laws of Duplicate Contract Bridge that describes, in general terms, proper conduct as to the exchange of information concerning a hand, as to attitude and etiquette, as to partnership agreements, and as to spectators' conduct.
words.name: Proprieties

words.def: See balance. (In the UK, protect is the more usual term.)
words.name: Protect

words.def: See appeal. (In the UK, appeal is the more usual term.)
words.name: Protest

words.def: A position that, to a defender, appears to be a true squeezed position, but is not. Declarer hopes that the defender will misplay as a result. The literature often gives as an example a position in which declarer has a void in dummy's apparent suit of entry.
words.name: Pseudo squeeze

words.def: A call that grossly misstates high card strength or distribution, made so as to deceive the opponents. The Laws specify that psychic bids themselves are legal. It is, however, a violation to infer and fail to disclose that partner has psyched, when the inference is based on partnership agreement or experience. Sponsoring organizations regulate the use of certain psychic bids.
words.name: Psych, psyche, psychic, or psychic bid

words.def: A bid that, by partnership agreement, announces that the player's previous bid was a psychic.
words.name: Psychic control

words.def: 1) To remove the opponents' trumps.2) To remove partner's double.
words.name: Pull

words.def: To force out an opponent's trump, usually by means of a forcing defense.
words.name: Pump

words.def: An artificial bid that simply requests partner to make a specified cheap reply – commonly the cheapest sufficient bid, or next step.
words.name: Puppet

words.def: A version of Stayman employed after an opening bid of 1NT or 2NT which could include a five-card major.
words.name: Puppet Stayman

words.def: 1) (Verb) To force the opponents to make any subsequent call at a level higher than they have as yet.2) (Noun) A tied board in a pairs or team duplicate event.
words.name: Push

words.def: A portmanteau of queen and jack. Used in situations where it does not matter whether the queen or the jack is held or played, as well as to emphasize that it does not matter. The term generalizes to other equals, such as jack and ten.[citation needed] See Principle of restricted choice.
words.name: Quack

words.def: (Adjective) A session or sessions preliminary to the final of an event.
words.name: Qualifying

words.def: 1) Of a bid: A call based, usually, on high card points, rather than a feature such as fit or shortness. A raise from 1NT to 3NT based on a 4-3-3-3 hand with 10 HCP is a quantitative raise.2) Of scoring: The method of scoring used in rubber bridge or in IMP events. The metric used is the number of points earned on each deal, perhaps adjusted by the IMP scale and victory points. In contrast, comparative scoring is based on the number of pairs that have been out-scored.
words.name: Quantitative

words.def: In Key Card Blackwood, the cheapest bid over the response to 4NT, to ask responder for the trump queen.
words.name: Queen ask, or queen-ask

words.def: Compare honor tricks.[contradictory]
words.name: Quick tricks

words.def: A trick whose cards have all been turned face down (duplicate bridge) or gathered in front of the trick's winner (rubber bridge). In rubber bridge, a player may inspect a quitted trick if his side has not yet led to the next trick. In duplicate bridge, a player may inspect a quitted trick only if told to do so by a director.
words.name: Quitted trick

words.def: Points won divided by the sum of points won and points lost, occasionally used to break a tie.
words.name: Quotient

words.def: A movement used in individual events.
words.name: Rainbow

words.def: A bid of partner's suit at a higher level. A raise shows a fit for partner's suit. 1?–2? is a single raise; 1?–3? is a double raise.
words.name: Raise

words.def: 1) The position of an individual card relative to others: Aces have the highest rank, followed by K, Q, J, 10, ... 2.2) The order of denominations in the bidding. Notrump is highest-ranked denomination, followed by spades, hearts, diamonds and clubs. A higher-ranked suit may be bid at the same level as a lower-ranked suit; the reverse is not true.
words.name: Rank

words.def: 1) Second and subsequent bids by the same player.2) A bid by the same player in a suit he has already bid.
words.name: Rebid

words.def: A suit with sufficient length and strength, according to partnership agreements, to be rebid in certain defined circumstances.
words.name: Rebiddable suit

words.def: (Abbreviation of "recapitulation") A summary of results in a bridge tournament.
words.name: Recap

words.def: A member of a bridge organization whose responsibility it is to maintain a record of reports of possible violations of the Proprieties.
words.name: Recorder

words.def: To lose some number of tricks in preparation for a squeeze. Losing the tricks "tightens up" the end position, removing idle cards from the defenders' hands before they can be used as safe discards in the squeezed position.
words.name: Rectify the count

words.def: (Slang) Vulnerable. From the color of the paint on a duplicate board. Also: "Red vs. red" to mean both sides vulnerable, and "red vs. white" to mean vulnerable vs. not. (In British slang, those last two expressions are rarely used. The more usual ones are: "(at) game all", "both red" or "(at) red all"; and "at unfavourable", "at red", "red against green" or "red against not".)
words.name: Red

words.def: In rubber bridge, the prescribed remedy for a faulty deal. In duplicate bridge, redeals are not used except in special cases and under a director's supervision.
words.name: Redeal

words.def: A call that doubles the penalties and bonuses that apply to a previous double. Used conventionally, a redouble may also convey additional information.
words.name: Redouble

words.def: A card that enables a hand to gain the lead on a later trick, after that hand has already gained the lead with a different entry card.
words.name: Re-entry

words.def: (Verb). Of a trick, to duck.
words.name: Refuse

words.def: To fail to comply with a bid that has made a request, such as an invitation or a transfer.
words.name: Reject

words.def: An artificial bid that requests partner to further describe his hand. The relay is usually the lowest available bid, so as to leave as much room for description as possible.
words.name: Relay bid, or relay

words.def: A bidding system that consists of many relay bid sequences.
words.name: Relay system

words.def: (Slang) Redouble; by extension from lever.
words.name: Relever or re-lever

words.def: To bid on over an undesired contract, especially a doubled contract.
words.name: Remove

words.def: Informal term for Revoke; associated with other games such as whist.
words.name: Renege

words.def: See balance.
words.name: Reopen

words.def: A form of knockout competition in which winners advance and losers drop into a secondary event from which some number of top performers return to the primary event. [clarification needed]
words.name: Repechage

words.def: To remove from a contract that partner has bid and which, often, has been doubled.
words.name: Rescue

words.def: Opening bidder's partner.
words.name: Responder

words.def: A bid by responder immediately following an opening bid and RHO's call.
words.name: Response

words.def: A double that follows LHO's opening bid, partner's takeout double and RHO's raise of opener's suit, to show moderate values and no clear opinion as to the best strain.
words.name: Responsive double

words.def: (Slang) One who evaluates bids and plays according to their outcome, rather than to their intrinsic merit. Also, "Result player" and "Second guesser".
words.name: Result merchant

words.def: Maintain the right to lead to the next trick by leading and winning the current trick.
words.name: Retain the lead

words.def: To lead back, usually the suit that partner led.
words.name: Return

words.def: A bidding sequence in which a single player, on consecutive calls, bids two different suits, and bids the two suits in the reverse order to that expected by the basic bidding system. The specific definition of a reverse therefore depends on the bidding system (see main article). The reverse is designed to show additional strength without the need to make a jump bid. Because the reverse takes up bidding space, the reverse bidder is usually expected to hold a stronger than average hand, usually more than 16 HCP.
words.name: Reverse

words.def: Failure to follow suit as required when a player is able to do so.
words.name: Revoke

words.def: (Slang) To redouble.
words.name: Rewind

words.def: Right-hand opponent.
words.name: RHO

words.def: To play a high card in the hope of taking a trick: "Rise with the ace." Also, "go up with"
words.name: Rise, as "rise with"

words.def: Roman Key Card Blackwood, a slam bidding convention.
words.name: RKCB

words.def: Descriptive of bids and carding agreements used or originated in the Roman system:1) Roman 2♣ and 2♦: Three-suiters.2) Roman Blackwood, Gerber and Roman Key Card Blackwood (RKCB): Step responses to the ace-asking bid that entail mild ambiguity.3) Roman jump overcall: Two-suiter.4) Roman asking bid: A request that partner bid his number of controls wholesale, via step responses.5) Roman discards: odd-even discards.6) Roman leads: Rusinow leads.
words.name: Roman

words.def: Acronym for Raise Only Non-Force. A treatment used for responding to preempts, usually weak two bids. All bids except the single raise are forcing.
words.name: RONF

words.def: The award for winning the world knockout team championship that is held in even numbered years other than leap years. (The Bermuda Bowl is contested in odd numbered years and the World Team Olympiad in leap years.)
words.name: Rosenblum Cup

words.def: The progression of the bidding and play in a clockwise direction around the table.
words.name: Rotation

words.def: A bidding system popular in the U.S. during the 1960s. It features sound opening bids, five-card majors and negative doubles. It is the principle foundation for 2/1 Game Forcing.
words.name: Roth–Stone

words.def: 1) In the bidding, a sequence of four consecutive calls.2) In duplicate bridge, a set of boards leading to another round (e.g., the semi-final round), or a set of boards that two pairs play against one another.3) Of a control, the round on which the control can stop the opponents from winning a trick. An ace, for example, is a first round control; the king is a second round control.
words.name: Round

words.def: Hearts or clubs. The term refers to the shape at the tops of the suit symbols. Contrast Pointed suit.
words.name: Rounded suit

words.def: An event format in which each team eventually opposes each other team.
words.name: Round-robin tournament, or round-robin

words.def: In rubber bridge, the set of successive deals that ends when one of the pairs wins two games.
words.name: Rubber

words.def: A bonus awarded to the pair winning the rubber: 500 points if the losers are vulnerable, 700 if they are not.
words.name: Rubber bonus

words.def: The original form of contract bridge, a contest with four players in two opposing pairs (as distinct from duplicate bridge, which requires a minimum of eight players).
words.name: Rubber bridge

words.def: Transfer advances of overcalls. See Useful Space Principle.
words.name: Rubens advances

words.def: To play a trump on a trick when a plain suit was led.
words.name: Ruff

words.def: The lead of a suit in which both opponents are void, so that one opponent can ruff while the other discards (or sluffs). A ruff and discard is usually damaging to the side that leads to the trick. Also, ruff and sluff or ruff and slough.
words.name: Ruff and discard

words.def: To establish a suit by ruffing one or more of its low cards.
words.name: Ruff out

words.def: 1) Devised by Ely Culbertson. "The total of defensive honor-tricks that will be won at any bid (trump or no-trump) after each deal is about 8 out of the 13 tricks."2) A way to decide whether to overcall an opponent's 1NT opening. Length in long suits, the losing trick count and HCP are combined.3) Devised by David Burn from experience of playing with and of captaining teams of junior players. (1) Subtract the number of aces held by opponents from eight. (2) Don't play at that level.
words.name: Rule of Eight

words.def: Regulation by the World Bridge Federation stipulating that an opening bid is acceptable if the sum of the number of cards in the two longest suits plus the number of HCP is at least 18.
words.name: Rule of Eighteen

words.def: A calculation that can be used when it is assumed that opening leader has led the fourth highest card in a suit. By subtracting the pips on the card led from 11, the result is the number of cards in the other three hands that are higher than the one led. Third hand, for example, can then make inferences about declarer's holding in the suit by examining his own and dummy's holdings; likewise, declarer can make inferences about right-hand-opponent's holding in the suit. (The rule can be modified to subtract from 12 if the lead is thought to be third best, and from 10 if the lead is thought to be fifth best.)
words.name: Rule of Eleven

words.def: Guideline for opening light in fourth seat: open if your high card points plus your number of spades is 15 or more. Also known as the Cansino Count.[7]
words.name: Rule of Fifteen

words.def: When the bidding has reached the 5-level in a competitive auction, tend to defend rather than bid on. In other words, in competitive auctions, 5-level contracts belong to the enemy. See also Law of Total Tricks
words.name: Rule of Five

words.def: Avoid giving support for partner's 5-card suit if a superior 4-4 fit might be available.
words.name: Rule of Four

words.def: When declarer's only high card in the suit lead by the opponents is the ace, count the number of cards in that suit held by declarer and dummy, subtract from seven and duck that many times.
words.name: Rule of Seven

words.def: On a competitive part score deal, with the points roughly equal between your side and theirs, once the bidding has reached the 3-level, tend to defend rather than bid on (unless your side has 9 trumps). See also Law of Total Tricks
words.name: Rule of Three

words.def: A widely used guideline of the Standard American Yellow Card (SAYC) bidding system which states that a hand may open bidding "normally" (that is, by bidding one of a suit) if the sum obtained by adding the combined length of its longest two suits to its high card points is twenty or more, but that weaker hands must either open with a preempive bid or pass. See also Zar points evaluation method.
words.name: Rule of Twenty

words.def: When missing two non-touching honors, it is normally superior to finesse first for their lower honor. In the following two example hands, three tricks or the maximum possible are needed.
words.name: Rule of Two

words.def: A bidding guide suggested by Ely Culbertson, which counsels preemptors to be within two tricks of their contract if vulnerable, and within three if not. Few players now follow the Rule of Two and Three.
words.name: Rule of Two and Three

words.def: A finding and decision by a tournament director or appeals committee.
words.name: Ruling

words.def: To play the winners in a suit.
words.name: Run

words.def: An agreement to lead the second highest of touching honors.
words.name: Rusinow leads

words.def: (Slang) Sacrifice. Also, "sack."
words.name: Sac

words.def: To deliberately bid over an opponent's bid, hoping that the cost of a penalty will be smaller than the value of opponent's presumed successful contract.
words.name: Sacrifice

words.def: A level at which the partnership can normally assume, on the basis of the previous bidding, that its contract will succeed. It is the point below which the partnership prefers to explore even higher contracts. Also, "security level."
words.name: Safety level

words.def: A play that maximizes the chances for fulfilling the contract (or for achieving a certain score) by avoiding a play which might result in a higher score. Contrast Percentage play, the best play in a suit, whereas a safety play is the best line for the contract.
words.name: Safety play

words.def: (Slang) To bid weakly or pass with good values, in the hope that the opponents will get overboard.
words.name: Sandbag

words.def: An overcall made after an opening bid and response by the opponents. The overcall is "sandwiched" between two hands that have each shown strength.
words.name: Sandwich

words.def: (Slang) Sacrifice.
words.name: Save

words.def: Standard American Yellow Card, a particular bidding system or the completed ACBL convention card that represents it.
words.name: SAYC

words.def: A style of bidding that attempts to narrowly limit the strength of a partnership's hands, so as to make its bidding more accurate.
words.name: Scientific

words.def: A loser-on-loser play meant to break the opponents' communications. Formerly known as 'Coup without a name'.
words.name: Scissors coup

words.def: 1) The numeric result of a deal, session or event.2) (Verb) Of a card, to win a trick: "The ♠Q scored."
words.name: Score, or bridge scoring

words.def: A paper form used to record the result of each deal in a duplicate bridge event when electronic scoring devices are not available. Depending upon the event format, the score slip may be either a pick-up slip or a traveller.
words.name: Score slip

words.def: 1) To bid to a safer contract.2) To score small trumps by ruffing, rather than as long cards. Often used of the play of a contract based on a Moysian fit.
words.name: Scramble

words.def: A device which divides the table diagonally, visually separating partners from each other. Used in higher-level competition to reduce the possibility of unauthorized information.
words.name: Screen

words.def: Opponents who sit on the same side of the screen.
words.name: Screenmates

words.def: Position relative to the dealer: for example, dealer's LHO is said to be in second seat.
words.name: Seat

words.def: See result merchant.
words.name: Second guesser

words.def: The player to the left of the player who has led to a trick.
words.name: Second hand

words.def: A precept that advises second hand to play a low card on RHO's lead. See also Third hand high.
words.name: Second hand low

words.def: A group of contestants in an event.
words.name: Section

words.def: A ranking assigned to a contestant of relatively high rank.
words.name: Seed

words.def: See Entry-shifting squeeze.
words.name: See-saw squeeze

words.def: A hand with 5-4-2-2 or 6-3-2-2 distribution.
words.name: Semi-balanced hand

words.def: A bid which is conditionally forcing: one which requests partner to rebid unless his hand is minimal or sub-minimal for his previous bidding. Compare invitation.
words.name: Semi-forcing bid

words.def: 1) The auction, or calls made in the auction.2) Two or more cards adjacent in rank.
words.name: Sequence

words.def: A period of play during which those entered in an event play designated boards against designated opponents.
words.name: Session

words.def: 1) To defeat a contract.2) The number of tricks by which a contract is defeated ("a two-trick set").
words.name: Set

words.def: In rubber bridge, an agreement that partners will not change at the end of each rubber.
words.name: Set game

words.def: Establish.
words.name: Set up

words.def: (Of a call) A call that is not quite warranted by the strength of the hand making it.
words.name: Shaded

words.def: The distribution of suits in a hand.
words.name: Shape

words.def: 1) (Verb) To lead a suit other than the one already played.2) (Noun) In the bidding, a change of suit, usually said of a jump bid (see jump shift).
words.name: Shift

words.def: To try for an unusually good result by adopting an abnormal line of play, typically at matchpoint scoring. Declarer hopes that the cards are distributed in such a way that a superior line of play will fail.
words.name: Shoot

words.def: The natural opening bid of 1♣ when the suit contains three cards or less. Usually employed by players using the five-card majors treatment for opening bids when holding a hand with opening values but lacking a five-card major. When the hand contains two clubs and three diamonds, an opening diamond bid is preferred. Also, "short diamond." These bids may also be called "prepared minors" - "prepared club" and "prepared diamond", or "better minor" bids. The EBU "Orange Book" recommends the term "prepared club" for bids that show a minimum of three cards, and "short club" where it may only be two cards or less.
words.name: Short club

words.def: 1) In a 13-card hand, a singleton or void suit.2) In a hand, that suit with the fewest cards.
words.name: Short suit

words.def: By agreement, a bid of a short side suit after a single raise, hoping to reach game. For example, after 1♥ - 2♥, opener might rebid 3♣ with a singleton or void in clubs. The bid tells partner where high cards will be least useful, indicating duplication of values. It requests partner to take positive action with high-card strength outside that suit. Otherwise, the bid requests partner to sign off (in this example, by bidding 3♥). See help-suit game try and game try.
words.name: Short suit game try

words.def: In hand evaluation, points counted for singletons and voids.
words.name: Short-suit points

words.def: Fail to follow suit.
words.name: Show out

words.def: To mix the cards. Shuffling seldom results in random distributions: in the long run, the cards so mixed rarely match the mathematical expectancies.
words.name: Shuffle

words.def: Partnership.
words.name: Side

words.def: A secondary event played simultaneously with the main event.
words.name: Side game

words.def: A suit that is not trump; plain suit. A side suit may nevertheless have significant length: see Two-suiter.
words.name: Side suit

words.def: The conventional meanings assigned to plays made by the defenders in order to exchange information. Also, carding.
words.name: Signals

words.def: 1) A bid that requests that partner pass.2) A call that denies extra values, one that normally results in a pass by partner. Compare non-forcing bid, forcing bid.
words.name: Signoff bid

words.def: To make a signoff bid.
words.name: Sign off

words.def: A sheet, typically of card or plastic, placed in the center of the table during the bidding period, and marked with numeral, suit and other symbols such that a player can indicate a call by tapping on them with a finger, writing implement, or the like. Largely superseded by bidding boxes.
words.name: Silent bidder

words.def: A squeeze against one opponent, in two suits, with the count (definition 3).
words.name: Simple squeeze

words.def: The normal manner of play, with certain knowledge only of one's own cards and dummy's, and without verbal communication between partners. Contrast Double dummy.
words.name: Single dummy

words.def: A holding of exactly one card in a suit.
words.name: Singleton

words.def: A round in a movement during which a pair is idle. That pair is said to "sit out" that round.
words.name: Sit-out

words.def: An irregular feature of a Mitchell movement: typically a move by the East–West pairs of 2 tables up instead of the usual 1, to avoid them playing the same boards twice.
words.name: Skip

words.def: A warning to LHO that one is about to make a jump bid that could cause a revealing hesitation or huddle; used only when bidding screens are not in place. The warning is made in one of two ways:1) When bidding boxes are in use, the red Stop card is placed on the table followed by a bid card; LHO is expected to wait 10 seconds before taking action;2) When bidding boxes are not in use, the jump bidder announces "I am about to make a skip bid, please wait." and then bids. LHO waits 10 seconds.
words.name: Skip bid warning, or skip-bid warning

words.def: 1) small slam (or simply, slam): a contract to win at least twelve tricks.2) grand slam: a contract to win all thirteen tricks.
words.name: Slam

words.def: A bid that invites partner to bid a slam.
words.name: Slam try

words.def: (Slang) The location of a card that is onside. "In the slot" means "Finessable."
words.name: Slot

words.def: Discard. Pronounced and sometimes spelled "sluff".
words.name: Slough

words.def: Cards that require establishment before they can be cashed.
words.name: Slow

words.def: A style of bidding that uses a jump to a contract (to which the previous bidding has already forced the partnership) to show a specific holding. Contrast Fast arrival.
words.name: Slow arrival

words.def: A rubber completed in three games. See fast rubber.
words.name: Slow rubber

words.def: See discard. Neo-orthography for slough, as used in ruff and sluff.
words.name: Sluff

words.def: (Slang) Same meaning as crack.
words.name: Smack

words.def: A contract for six odd tricks.
words.name: Small slam

words.def: The Smith signal (also known as Smith echo or Smith peter) is an attitude carding signal in contract bridge showing additional values (or lack thereof) in the first suit led by the defence, while the signal itself is given in the first suit played by declarer.
words.name: Smith signal

words.def: After opener has denied a four-card major in a Stayman sequence, responder's jump to 3M to show four cards in the bid major and five cards in the other major.
words.name: Smolen

words.def: An endplay that captures an opponent's guarded trump by means of an overruff, when that card cannot be finessed in the normal fashion.
words.name: Smother play

words.def: Lower honors, as distinct from aces and kings.
words.name: Soft values

words.def: A suit strong enough to run without interruption, or (in the bidding) that requires no fit with partner.
words.name: Solid

words.def: To arrange one's cards by suit, and by rank within suit.
words.name: Sort

words.def: A conventional redouble that asks partner for rescue from a doubled contract. Its name comes from the Morse code distress signal SOS.
words.name: SOS redouble

words.def: A hand that is relatively strong for a call that is contemplated or that has been made.
words.name: Sound

words.def: A variant of Texas in which 4♣ and 4♦ are used as transfers to 4♥ and 4♠ respectively.
words.name: South African Texas

words.def: An unusual jump bid that by agreement shows a fit for partner's last-bid suit and a singleton or void in the bid suit. For example, a partnership could treat 4♣ in response to an opening bid of 1♠ as a splinter bid, showing a good hand with spade support and a singleton or void club. Compare with Fragment bid.
words.name: Splinter bid

words.def: 1) (Noun) The distribution in the opponents' hands of the cards in a suit.2) (Verb) To play one of two touching honors when the lead comes through them.
words.name: Split

words.def: A menace in squeeze play which depends on values in both declarer's hand and dummy.
words.name: Split menace

words.def: 1) The organization that puts on a tournament, such as the WBF, the ACBL or the EBU, a regional association, or a club.2) One who hires partners or teammates to compete in an event.
words.name: Sponsor

words.def: A card that ranks below the 10.
words.name: Spot card

words.def: (Slang) Laydown.
words.name: Spread

words.def: A Suit Preference Signal, a card played by a defender to show interest in or an entry in a side suit.
words.name: SPS

words.def: A playing technique that forces the defender(s) to discard a vital card, usually an apparent stopper.
words.name: Squeeze

words.def: A card whose lead forces one or both defenders to discard their guard in a suit.
words.name: Squeeze card

words.def: A distribution of cards in defenders' hands that might make the play difficult for declarer. The defenders' trumps, for example, could be said to be stacked if they divide 5-0.
words.name: Stack

words.def: A bidding system thought to conform to agreements that an unfamiliar partnership in America would use.
words.name: Standard American or Standard American Yellow Card (SAYC)

words.def: Not called to change seats during the movement being used.
words.name: Stationary

words.def: A conventional bid of 2♣ that calls for a 1NT opening bidder to bid a four-card major, if one is held, and (usually) 2♦ otherwise. Many continuations have been devised.
words.name: Stayman convention

words.def: To gain an advantage, usually through deception. The theft may be material (e.g., a trick or a contract) or non-material (e.g., a tempo). Despite the term steal, deception is entirely legal if it does not involve unauthorized information or concealment of information to which the opponents are entitled.
words.name: Steal

words.def: In the bidding, the space between one bid and the next highest. See Useful Space Principle.
words.name: Step

words.def: A bid that conveys information on the basis of the number of steps it uses.
words.name: Step bid

words.def: A squeeze that forces a defender either to be thrown in to act as a stepping-stone to a stranded dummy, or to allow declarer to establish a suit.
words.name: Stepping-stone squeeze

words.def: (Slang, chiefly British) An 1100-point penalty. Compare "go for a number".
words.name: Sticks and wheels

words.def: (Slang, adjective and noun) A singleton.
words.name: Stiff

words.def: An instruction given to opponents when you make a jump bid, or skip bid. LHO is expected to wait around 10 seconds before calling, so as to avoid communicating information to partner as to how easy his call is to make. See skip-bid warning.
words.name: Stop

words.def: A high card (normally, an honor) whose primary function is to prevent the opponents from running a suit in a notrump contract. See also Control.
words.name: Stopper

words.def: See denomination.
words.name: Strain

words.def: 1) To remove safe cards of exit from an opponent's hand.2) To prepare for a ruff-and-sluff by removing all cards of a suit (or suits) in a partnership's hands.
words.name: Strip

words.def: A squeeze without the count in which one threat is against a safe exit card.
words.name: Strip squeeze

words.def: A double of a laydown contract made in hope of dissuading the opponents from successfully bidding to a higher, more rewarding contract. The doubler must be prepared to run (like the cowardly ape) to an escape suit if the opponents redouble.
words.name: Striped-tail ape double

words.def: A set of conventions that uses an opening bid of 1♣ as an artificial, forcing opening that promises a strong hand.
words.name: Strong club system

words.def: An opening notrump that shows a balanced hand and 15-17 or 16-18 HCP. Contrast Weak notrump. A partnership's choice between the use of a strong notrump or a weak notrump has extensive implications for its entire bidding system.
words.name: Strong notrump

words.def: A bidding system that mandates a pass by first (or second) hand to show what other systems would regard as an opening bid. A corollary is that if the next hand also passes, third (or fourth) hand must bid to keep the deal from being passed out.
words.name: Strong pass system

words.def: An agreement to use an opening bid of two of a suit so as to indicate a strong hand and a strong holding in the bid suit.
words.name: Strong two bid, strong two-bid, or Strong Two

words.def: (Slang) Part-score.
words.name: Stub

words.def: (Slang) An ill-advised penalty double, such as one based on HCP when the bidding warns of freak distributions.
words.name: Sucker double

words.def: A ranked division of the deck of cards into (in descending rank order) spades, hearts, diamonds and clubs. The suit ranking has a profound effect on the bidding and scoring, but none at all on the play. See also Denomination, Major suit, and Minor suit).
words.name: Suit

words.def: A defensive carding method that signals a preference, or the lack thereof, for a suit other than the suit used for the signal.
words.name: Suit preference signal

words.def: A strongly encouraging response to a transfer, such as a jump completion (e.g., 1NT - 2♥; 3♠). Many partnerships use a conventional superacceptance such as 1NT - 2♦; 2♠, one step above responder's major, to save room for game or slam exploration, and in conformance with the Useful Space Principle.
words.name: Superaccept

words.def: A fit with partner's suit.
words.name: Support

words.def: A double of an overcall that shows a fit for partner's suit, usually distinguished from a direct raise by the length of the suit in responder's hand.
words.name: Support double

words.def: A trick that in the absence of some irregularity a player must win, such as the ace of trumps. Extended by George Coffin to refer to guaranteed lines of play.
words.name: Sure trick

words.def: A count or preference signal made in a different suit, usually the suit which declarer is running, to inform partner in beforehand about a critical decision he will have to make later during the play of the hand.
words.name: Surrogate signals

words.def: A deceptive bid or play.
words.name: Swindle

words.def: A proxi-acronym for Sebesfi Woods 1NT Escape.
words.name: SWINE

words.def: A difference in scores between two tables on a board in a team match.
words.name: Swing

words.def: (Slang) Three consecutive passes, ending the auction. "3♠ - swish" means 3♠ passed out.
words.name: Swish

words.def: A Swiss-system tournament for teams-of-four. Every team plays a series of matches with a series of opponents whose records or standings are as similar as possible when they face each other, without scheduling repeat matches. Typically these are relatively numerous, relatively short matches. For example, of 54 to 56 boards in one day's play: 6, 7, 8, or 9 matches of 9, 8, 7, or 6 boards respectively.
words.name: Swiss, or Swiss Teams

words.def: To lead a different suit.
words.name: Switch

words.def: see bidding system.
words.name: System

words.def: 1) (Noun) A grouping of four players at a bridge tournament.2) (Verb) To put down one's cards face up.3) See dummy (2).
words.name: Table

words.def: A large printed card placed on a table in a bridge tournament. The card contains instructions for the players, including players' designations and board numbers. Also, "Guide card."
words.name: Table card

words.def: Awareness of opponents' behavior and mannerisms, leading to inferences regarding their holdings and problems on a deal. It is improper to take action on inferences made on the basis of partner's behavior. Also, "Table feel."
words.name: Table presence

words.def: 1) Improper communication between partners, effected by words, gestures, or facial expressions.2) Extraneous discussion during the play, discouraged as a distraction or possible source of unauthorized information.
words.name: Table talk

words.def: A conventional call used in a competitive auction to indicate support for the unbid suits in a hand of opening strength, and to request that partner bid. The classic, ideal pattern is 4-4-4-1, with the shortness in the suit doubled. There are many informatory doubles that anticipate a bid from partner, but "takeout double" typically refers to the double immediately over opening bidder.
words.name: Takeout double

words.def: (Slang) Huddle.
words.name: Tank

words.def: (Verb and noun) Slang. To adopt a line of defense that is intended to force declarer to ruff in the long hand. Also, the line of defense itself: "To get the tap going." See Forcing defense.
words.name: Tap

words.def: 1) (Adjective) (also Teams or Team(s)-of-four) A form of duplicate bridge played by eight people at two tables. The North–South pair at one table and East–West pair at the other table are teammates. Every deal is played at both tables ("duplicate") and scored by comparing the two raw scores — usually on the IMP or board-a-match scale. Matches are commonly played in sets of 6 to 20 deals, with scoring required and player substitutions permitted between sets.2) (Noun) A group of four or more players who compete together in a teams event. For each deal, four team members are active at two tables. Player substitution occurs between matches or, in many longer matches, between sets of 6 to 20 deals. Most teams events permit four to six players on a team.
words.name: Team

words.def: A member of the same team. Commonly said of any teammate other than one's partner.
words.name: Teammate

words.def: (Adjective) See team (1)
words.name: Teams

words.def: 1) Having the timing advantage in the play of the cards by possessing the lead and thereby being able to initiate (or continue) one's line of play before the declarer/opponents can establish his/theirs.2) The speed at which a player executes a call or play. Some players attempt to intimidate less experienced opponents by playing their cards very quickly. A break in tempo often indicates that a player has an unexpected problem in play.
words.name: Tempo

words.def: Waiting bid.
words.name: Temporizing bid

words.def: A broken sequence of (often) honor cards, such as ♠ A Q or ♦ K J. Declarer may lead toward his or dummy's tenace, preparing to finesse for a missing card. A defender may lead through declarer's or dummy's tenace to help his partner score cards behind the tenace.
words.name: Tenace

words.def: A convention whereby a bid of 4♦ or 4♥ in response to a notrump bid requests partner to transfer to 4♥ or 4♠ respectively.
words.name: Texas transfer, or Texas

words.def: (Slang) A hand on which the opponents have the preponderance of strength.
words.name: Their hand

words.def: (Slang) 1) A bid or contract based on less strength than normally recommended.2) (Of a hand) Lacking body.
words.name: Thin

words.def: An opening lead convention that calls for the lead of the third-best card in a suit of up to four card length, and the fifth-best in a longer suit.
words.name: Third-and-fifth

words.def: An opening lead convention that calls for the lead of the third-best card from a suit with an even number of cards, and the lowest card from a suit with an odd number of cards.
words.name: Third from even, low from odd

words.def: The player who makes the third call, or who is the third to play to a trick.
words.name: Third hand

words.def: A precept that advises the third hand to play a high card on partner's lead. See also Second hand low.
words.name: Third hand high

words.def: A term for a bidding system combining 5-card majors and a weak no-trump.
words.name: Third Way

words.def: In squeeze play, a menace.
words.name: Threat

words.def: A hand with length in three suits, thus shortness in the fourth. Distributions such as 4-4-4-1, 5-4-4-0 and 5-4-3-1 are often termed "three-suiters."
words.name: Three suiter

words.def: To discard.
words.name: Throw

words.def: See Endplay.
words.name: Throw-in

words.def: (Slang) An honor card or honor sequence unaccompanied by low cards: "He had the ♥KQ tight."
words.name: Tight

words.def: A player's agenda for tasks in the play of the hand: for example, ruff losers and then draw trumps; or, draw trumps and then run the side suit.
words.name: Timing

words.def: Playing matchpoints, the highest score achieved on a board.
words.name: Top

words.def: The lead of a high spot card from a suit that contains no honor card.
words.name: Top of nothing

words.def: A card that can take a trick on a given hand. See Winner.
words.name: Top trick

words.def: The sum of the number of tricks that each partnership can take, with its longest combined suit as trump. See Law of Total tricks.
words.name: Total tricks

words.def: Adjacent. Both cards and suits may be touching. In the holding ♣KQ5, the king and queen are touching. In deciding whether to respond Up the line, a player notes that hearts and spades are touching suits.
words.name: Touching

words.def: An organized duplicate bridge competition.
words.name: Tournament

words.def: (Slang) Huddle.
words.name: Trance

words.def: A bid that conventionally shows length in a suit other than the one bid, or requests partner to make a bid in a particular suit, or both. The suit in question is usually the suit immediately above the one bid. Examples: Jacoby transfers (often just called "transfers") and Texas transfers ("Texas"). Also, see transfer a control.
words.name: Transfer

words.def: Cards, such as aces and kings, that are valuable either in declarer's hands or in defenders'.
words.name: Transferable values

words.def: In squeeze play, to shift the responsibility of controlling, or guarding, a menace from one opponent to the other. This is usually accomplished by playing through one opponent in a way that forces him to cover the lead, leaving the other opponent with the remaining control. The purpose is to arrange that one opponent has to guard more menaces than he can successfully manage.
words.name: Transfer a control

words.def: 1) A pair or team whose members differ in "nationality". Typically they are members of different national bridge federations, thus registered players.2) An event (tournament) that permits transnational pairs or teams to enter. A transnational event is open in sense (c).
words.name: Transnational

words.def: See Sandbag.
words.name: Trap pass

words.def: A type of score slip on which the result of a deal is recorded for the purpose of comparative scoring. Used in certain event formats, it is folded, placed into the board and 'travels' with it to the next table. May also be referred to as a travelling slip or travelling score sheet.[6] Contrast Pick-up slip.
words.name: Traveller

words.def: See Board.
words.name: Tray

words.def: A natural bid that: (1) either shows a willingness to play in the denomination named, or promises or requests values in that denomination, and (2) by partnership agreement gives or requests additional information on which action could be based. If the treatment is an unusual one, it requires announcement to the opponents even though it is natural. For example, a partnership that plays Flannery usually agrees that a 1♠ response to a 1♥ opening bid shows five spades. So the 1♠ response to 1♥, while natural, is a treatment because by agreement it shows at least a five card suit. Compare with Convention, in the auction a call that gives or requests information not necessarily related to the denomination named.
words.name: Treatment

words.def: A tripleton.
words.name: Trebleton

words.def: See game try.
words.name: Trial bid

words.def: A (usually, high-level) tournament whose winners proceed to a subsequent event of even greater import.
words.name: Trial

words.def: A set of four cards played by each player in turn, during the play of a hand.
words.name: Trick

words.def: The score earned by contracting for and taking tricks. Trick scores count toward making a game.
words.name: Trick score

words.def: A squeeze that is so-named because it consists of three simple squeezes against the same opponent. A Progressive squeeze is regarded as a triple squeeze (because it is initiated by one), but not all triple squeezes are progressive.
words.name: Triple squeeze

words.def: A holding of three cards in a suit.
words.name: Tripleton

words.def: 1) (Noun) A card in the trump suit whose trick-taking power is greater than any plain suit card.2) (Verb) To play a trump after a plain suit has been led; see Ruff.
words.name: Trump

words.def: The ability, from a combination of the holding in trumps with play technique, to prevent the opponents from taking too many tricks in a plain suit.
words.name: Trump control

words.def: An echo in the trump suit, long used to alert partner to the possibility of a defensive ruff, and in the early 21st century to give partner the count.
words.name: Trump echo

words.def: The advancement of a trump to the status of a winner by creating a position in which an opponent must suffer an uppercut, or an immediate adverse overruff, or choose to ruff with a higher trump that makes a later winner of an opponent's trump by force of cards.
words.name: Trump promotion

words.def: A squeeze that forces an opponent to weaken his holding in one of the threat suits enough that the suit can later be ruffed out.
words.name: Trump squeeze

words.def: By way of the auction, declarer and declarer's partner select the trump suit on the basis of their combined length and strength in the suit: the greater length to ruff more losers in the plain suits, and the greater strength to better control the play of the trump suit itself. Information about trump suits generally in other card games can be found here.
words.name: Trump suit, or simply "trumps"

words.def: A bidding system that uses an opening bid of 2♣ as an artificial game force.
words.name: Two club system, or Two clubs system

words.def: A hand containing two long suits, usually each containing 4 or more cards, with at least 10 cards between the two suits.
words.name: Two-suiter

words.def: An inquiry made after opener redbids 1NT. 2♣ is a puppet to 2♦ which says nothing about responders strain. It is just a forcing bid to show an invitational hand. On the other hand, a rebid of 2♦ after a 1NT rebid is an artificial game force.[clarification needed]
words.name: Two-way checkback

words.def: An inquiry about the third (or sometimes fourth) position opener's strength in a major suit. 2♣ shows 3-card support, while an inquiry made with 2♦ shows four cards in opener's suit.
words.name: Two-way Drury

words.def: A finesse that could be taken through either opponent.
words.name: Two-way finesse

words.def: Over an opening bid of 1NT, the use of 2♣ as non-forcing Stayman and 2♦ as a game-forcing major suit inquiry.
words.name: Two-way Stayman

words.def: Information obtained from partner that one is not permitted to act on: for example, the manner in which partner plays a particular card, or the tone of voice when making a bid.
words.name: Unauthorized information

words.def: 1) Broadly, any distribution of a hand or suit other than 4-3-3-3, 4-4-3-2 or 5-3-3-2.2) Unbalanced is commonly used in a narrow sense that excludes semi-balanced, 5-4-2-2 and 6-3-2-2. Narrowly, unbalanced distribution implies a void, singleton, or 7-card suit.
words.name: Unbalanced distribution

words.def: A 13-card hand with unbalanced distribution in the broad or narrow sense just above.
words.name: Unbalanced hand

words.def: A suit that has neither been bid nor indirectly shown.
words.name: Unbid suit

words.def: To play a card whose rank interferes with the use of cards in the opposite hand. Opposite dummy's KQJ, declarer's singleton ace blocks the suit, and so is played to unblock. There are other situations that require unblocking, such as the Vienna coup.
words.name: Unblock

words.def: See In front of.
words.name: Under

words.def: 1) (Verb) To bid less aggressively, or to a lower contract, than most would with the same cards.2) (Noun) A bid that most would regard as weaker than warranted by the strength of the hand.
words.name: Underbid

words.def: To lead a low card when holding the top card or cards in a suit. The underlead is standard in defense of notrump contracts (so as to preserve communications between defenders' hands), but unusual against suit contracts.
words.name: Underlead

words.def: To play a trump lower than one already played on the lead of a plain suit. Usually this is undesirable but is sometimes necessary to adjust the number of trumps held while preparing a trump coup, or while preparing to defend certain squeezed positions.
words.name: Underruff

words.def: A trick that declarer does not win, causing the contract to go down. Multiple undertricks occur: for example, two undertricks could result in 4♥ down two.
words.name: Undertrick

words.def: A rubber that the players agree not to finish. In rubber bridge scoring, a 300-point bonus is given to a vulnerable side, and a 100-point bonus to a side with a part score - note this differs from the 50 points for a part score in duplicate bridge.
words.name: Unfinished rubber

words.def: To discard lower cards that help prevent a higher card from being captured by an opponent.
words.name: Unguard

words.def: See wide-ranging bid.
words.name: Unlimited bid

words.def: Unpassed hand.
words.name: UPH

words.def: 1) (Of a contract) Unable to be played so as to bring about a favorable outcome.2) (Of an agreement) Inevitably bringing about undesirable bidding sequences or contracts.
words.name: Unplayable

words.def: An artificial jump overcall in notrump that shows a Two-suiter, usually bid to suggest a sacrifice. As originally played, 1M - (2NT) showed a hand weak in high cards with, probably, 5-5 in the minor suits.
words.name: Unusual notrump

words.def: A conventional method of conveying information after the opponents have deployed the unusual notrump convention or a Michaels Cue Bid, also called Unusual vs. Unusual.
words.name: Unusual over unusual (OUO), or Unusual vs. unusual

words.def: Acronym or initialism for Unusual over unusual
words.name: UOU

words.def: To bid the lower of two adjacent suits before the higher. For example, of two four card majors, the heart suit is normally bid before the spade suit in response to an opening bid of 1♣ or 1♦.
words.name: Up the line

words.def: To ruff in the expectation of being overruffed, when the overruff will cause a trump in partner's hand to become a winner.
words.name: Uppercut

words.def: An agreement that when following suit to partner's lead, a low card encourages a continuation and a high card discourages. This is "upside-down", or the reverse of traditional practice.
words.name: Upside-down signals

words.def: United States Bridge Championships, competitions sponsored by the USBF in which entries compete to represent the United States in world tournaments. The USBC are teams-of-four tournaments that determine "USA" open, women, and senior teams. Sometimes the USBC winner and runner-up both qualify, as teams "USA1" and "USA2".
words.name: USBC

words.def: United States Bridge Federation, the association charged with national representation of the United States in international competition. Contrast ACBL.
words.name: USBF

words.def: A guide to developing bidding conventions and treatments that directs developers' attention to the allocation of bidding space.
words.name: Useful space principle

words.def: Variable Cue Bidding. Agreements used in the Ultimate Club to request and show controls.
words.name: VCB

words.def: The use of a weak notrump when not vulnerable and a strong notrump when vulnerable.
words.name: Variable notrump

words.def: A conversion scale used in team contests and based on total IMP differences, so as to reduce the effect of very large swings.
words.name: Victory points (VP)

words.def: The unblock of a winner opposite a threat prior to reaching a position that effects a squeeze.
words.name: Vienna coup

words.def: An assumption about how the cards lie on a particular deal: "Sorry, partner, I took a view."
words.name: View

words.def: No cards in a given suit.
words.name: Void

words.def: See Exclusion Blackwood.
words.name: Voidwood

words.def: A method of visually displaying tournament bridge deals to spectators, by optical or electronic means.
words.name: Vugraph, or viewgraph

words.def: The scoring condition of each pair in advance of a deal. In duplicate bridge and Chicago, vulnerability is pre-determined for each board or deal; in rubber bridge, it is determined by the number of games completed in the rubber. Vulnerability affects both the size of bonuses for making contracts and penalties for failing to make them.
words.name: Vulnerability

words.def: 1) (Duplicate bridge) A designation, shown on each board, that indicates whether larger bonuses and penalties apply to one, both or neither pair on that deal.2) (Rubber bridge) Having won one game.
words.name: Vulnerable

words.def: A bid that enables the bidder to obtain more information before making a commitment. For example, some players use 2♦ over a 2♣ forcing opening bid as a waiting bid rather than as a negative response.
words.name: Waiting bid

words.def: To condone an irregularity. In duplicate bridge, a waiver is an improper action.
words.name: Waive

words.def: (Slang) Push.
words.name: Wash

words.def: Duplicated values.
words.name: Wasted values

words.def: World Bridge Federation.
words.name: WBF

words.def: A jump overcall used to preempt the bidding.
words.name: Weak jump overcall

words.def: A jump shift used to preempt the bidding.
words.name: Weak jump shift

words.def: A 1NT opening bid on a balanced hand with, usually, 12-14 HCP. The bid has mild preemptive value; contrast Strong notrump. To show a strong notrump, the weak notrump user opens with a suit and rebids in notrump.
words.name: Weak notrump

words.def: Following a major suit raise to the two level, the weak suit game try names a suit with at least three cards and at least two losers where partner's short suit is likely to be useful, as will a strong suit. Three small cards is ideal.2) Alternative term for a help suit game try. In some usage the "help suit game try" is barely distinguishable from the long, in some barely distinguishable from the weak.
words.name: Weak suit game try

words.def: An opening bid of two of a suit to indicate a relatively weak hand with a long suit.
words.name: Weak two bid, weak two-bid, or Weak Two

words.def: A trick-taking card game and predecessor to contract bridge.
words.name: Whist

words.def: A count or total that obscures cards' identities. A bid of 5♥ in response to Blackwood shows two aces wholesale, without announcing which aces they are.
words.name: Wholesale

words.def: (Said of a suit) Without a stopper.
words.name: Wide open
